Approximately 40 species of Hedyotis, formerly recognized under Houstonia L. and Oldenlandia L. (Lewis, 1961) Stevens (1912) reported n = 16 for H. caerulea (L.) Hook. which Fagerlind (1937) recorded as n = 18. Terrell (1959) , in a revision of the H. purpurea (L.) T. & G. complex, listed several preliminary counts but these were all approximations. Lewis (1959) (Hagerup, 1932; Raghaven and Rangaswamy, 1941 ) and

these are distributed in a series of x = 9 with 2 diploid, 5 tetraploid, and 1 octoploid species. A majority of the Rubiaceae with known chromosome numbers, totaling only 6% of the described species but from diverse tribes, have a basic number of x = 11. This suggests a high degree of morphological differentiation in the family without change in chromosome number (Stebbins, 1950) . The preliminary studies in Hedyotis, however, indicate that the genus might be an exception to such a correlation. Therefore, one purpose of this study was to establish the chromosome numbers of the morphologically most varied species in North America in order to ascertain if H edyotis followed the cytological pattern so far observed for the Rubiaceae. To these data the results from morphology, geography, and ecology are added in an attempt to trace the phylogeny of the subg. Edrisia.

MATERIALS AND METHODs-The chromosomes of 90 collections totalling about 85% of the North American species of Hedyotis have been studied from localities throughout the range of the species. Immature flower buds were fixed in the field in a solution of 4 parts chloroform, 3 parts absolute ethyl alcohol, 1 part glacial acetic acid; as soon as possible after fixation, the buds were stored at refrigerator temperatures for periods up to 6 months without significant deterioration. Flower buds were squashed in 1% aceticorcein and meiotic (PMC's), or more rarely mitotic figures were examined. Chromosome drawings were made with the aid of a camera lucida giving in total a magnification of 2300 X, here reduced by ca. % for reproduction.

As noted in Table 1 , seeds from a number of herbarium specimens were cultured on a medium containing 1% agar-agar, 0.5% glucose, 0.0001% potassium gibberellate, and an antibiotic solution with 100 ,ug/ml amphotericin B, 4 ,ug/ml dihydrostreptomycin sulfate, 4 ,ug/ml neomycin sulfate, and 400 ,ug/ml thiostrepton (Lewis and Elvin-Lewis, 1961) . Following the fixation and staining procedures outlined for the bud material, mitosis was observed in rapidly growing apical meristems of seedlings grown in this medium after pretreatment in paradichlorobenzene for 2 hr.

Voucher specimens are filed in the Southern Methodist University Herbarium except for several collections listed in Table 1 which are deposited elsewhere. Duplicates have been distributed for most collections to either the University of Texas, Stanford University, or U.S. National Museum. I am indebted to the curators of these herbaria, who also made available their collections of Hedyotis, for their aid. I also appreciate the assistance of those collectors listed in Table 1 , particularly Dr. E. E. Terrell, U.S.D.A., Beltsville, Md., who contributed material for cytological study.

RESULTs-Chromosome numbers and voucher data for 39 taxa of Hedyotis are listed in Table 1 under the subgenera Edrisia and Oldenlandia. Although the subg. Oldenlandia has few native species, basic numbers of x = 6 and 9 have been found with 9 the more common. For 25 species in the subg. Edrisia, basic numbers of x = 6, 7 8, 9(10), 11, and 13 occur, with 11 the most frequent. Chromosome numbers of n = 9 and 10 are reported for H. nigricans. Only 2 tetraploid and 1 hexaploid species were found, although H. caerulea, H. polypremoides, and H. purpurea have both 2x and 4x races. Chromosome size varies from very large for those species in the x = 6 series ( Fig. 1-6 ), large to intermediate in the x = 11 group (Fig. 17-24 ), and small in the x = 9 and 13 lines, with intermediate and small sizes typical of the subg. Edrisia (25) (26) (27) (28) (29) and the subg. Oldenlandia (Fig. 30-34 ). Irregular meiotic behavior was observed for 1 apparent autotetraploid individual of H. purpurea (Fig. 5 ), but otherwise meiosis was regular.

Most species of the subg. Edrisia occur in either a mesic environment of the humid south temperate zone or a xeric environment of the Mexican highlands and associated areas. In the latter, 5 perennial and 4 annual species are known, all with a basic number of x = 11 (Fig.   36 ). This is the most common number in the subgenus as it is in the Rubiaceae. An isolated group of species with morphological affinities to those in the x = 11 line are found in Baja California (Fig. 35) . In this group having x = 13 as a basic number, the 2 annuals are restricted to the Cape region while the perennials are found over the southern two-thirds of the peninsula. Haploid numbers of 9 and 10 are shared by H. nigricans, the only species common to both mesic and xeric habitats (Fig. 37 ). Those individuals with n = 10 are restricted to the western regions of distribution; those with n = 9 are more frequent and widespread. Four species occur in the x = 8 series. The diploid H. crassifolia is common throughout the southern U.S., H. caerulea is more frequent to the north, the tetraploid H. australis is limited to the south central U.S., and the hexaploid H. michauxii is confined to the upland region of the Appalachians (Fig. 38) . The 2 species in the x = 7 series are probably the least known, e.g., the 2x species H. rosea described by Rafinesque (1817) was not "rediscovered" until Mueller and Mueller (1936) distinguished the species as Houstonia pygmaea over a century later. The species is now recorded from 9 south central states, of much wider distribution than the 4x H. procumbens (Fig. 39) . Those species with a base of x = 6 have a wide range in eastern North America (Fig. 40) (Terrell, 1959) . In addition to H. purpurea, diploid and tetraploid races are known for other species in the complex (Lewis and Terrell, unpublished) . A number of evolutionary trends in morphological expression are generally acknowledged in angiosperm groups (cf. Constance, 1955) . Although exceptions to most so-called primitive and advanced characters can be cited, these are fewer and the trends are most apparent in a small group of related species. In Hedyotis subg. Edrisia, the perennial habit; fruticose, upright, tall stems; open large corollas; homostyly; cymose inflorescence; absence of cleistogamous flowers; numerous, small, non-specialized seeds; and diploidy, are usually generalized expressions and may be considered the primitive conditions. From these it is not difficult to explain the origin of the reduced or the specialized and differentiated conditions rather than the reverse trend. Among the more advanced characteristics are included the annual habit; herbaceous, short, prostrate stems; salverform, reduced corollas; solitary, heterostylous and short-styled flowers; cleistogamous flowers; and few, intermediatesized, morphologically specialized seeds (Table 2) . For most species a high degree of differentiation is correlated with polyploidy.

By assigning values of 0, 1, or 2 to primitive, intermediate or advanced expressions for the 13 characters, it is possible to rank the species according to their degree of advancement from the generalized condition. Thus, for 25 species of the subg. Edrisia initially separated by basic chromosome number, a range from a value of 4 for the most primitive species to 16 for the most advanced has been found (Table 3) . Among the aneuploid groups, the species with x = 13 are the least differentiated. This suggests that the species native to Baja California have remained closest to the primitive condition in the subgenus, a not uncommon characteristic of species in this region (Axelrod, 1960) . The only "derived" characters of the most primitive species, H. mucronata, are the salverform corollas and heterostylous flowers, both of which are common to many extant species of Hedyotis, and the few (ca. 25) seeds per capsule each of intermediate size (0.8 mm long). The species of the x = 11 group are more advanced than the preceding, although the perennial species have the suffruticose stems, thick root stocks, heterostylous flowers, and long, salverform corollas in common. The annual habit has been a major specialization in both lines, but in contrast to the annuals of the Cape region, those of northeastern Mexico and southern Texas are more specialized. Their stems are rarely more than 2 dm long, seeds are few per capsule andal] According to Baker (1959) , heterostyly in general insures outbreeding whereas the homostylous representatives of a heterostylous genus are habitual inbreeders. The short-styled species of such a genus must also be inbreeders, and, judging from the successful fruit sets for H. croftiae and H. greenmanii, they possess functional stigmas in contrast to functionless stigmas noted for similar flowers of Gouldia (Skottsberg, 1944) . These floral conditions, while insuring fertilization and increasing the opportunity for rapid colonization (Baker, 1955) The species is considered more primitive, how-ever, by having funnelform corollas and unspecialized seeds.

With the perennial or annual habit, heterostylous flowers, and often numerous (up to 100 per capsule) small seeds, H. caerulea ranks as the most generalized species of the x = 8 group. It is closely related to H. michauxii, a hexaploid species with prostrate stems confined to high altitudes. H edyotis caerulea is also related to the more specialized H. crassifolia, an annual with fewer and larger seeds, and short-styled flowers. The line is climaxed by H. australis, the most highly evolved species in the subgenus, which is similar to H. crassifolia except that the stems rarely exceed 1 dm tall, the corollas are reduced, and the species is tetraploid.

The 2 species in the x = 7 group have in common large salverform corollas, precocious anthesis, craterform concavo-convex seeds, and south temperate distributions. H edyotis rosea is an annual diploid species with very short stems (to 6 cm) and short-styled flowers. This species has many characteristics in common with H. crassifolia and resembles the latter more closely than H. procumbens in the same series. Although H. procumbens is somewhat more specialized than H. rosea with prostrate stems, cleistogamous flowers, and tetraploid in chromosome number, [Vol. 49 this species is heterostylous and perennial. Considered together, these species are the most specialized in the subgenus.

All species in x = 6 group are herbaceous perennials with slender root stocks, and have long funnelform corollas, heterostylous flowers in cymes, few specialized and intermediate-sized seeds, and very large chromosomes. The species are diploid or both diploid and tetraploid in chromosome number. The group is relatively primitive and although the species resemble H. exigula Lewis of southern Mexico, they also have an affinity with a number of Asian species.

Drscussrox-e-Representatives of Hedyotis subg. Edrisia are separable into 6 lines of descent, with those species in the x = 7, 8, and 11 groups the most specialized. There is considerable parallel development in these lines of which the annual habit, loss of long-styled flowers, reduction of corolla length, and concave-convex, craterform seeds with hilar ridges are the most conspicuous. Aneuploidy, by gain and loss of chromosomes from an x = 11 stock, has been dominant in the evolution of the subgenus. Only 12% of the species are polyploid, but the recent development of polyploid complexes in 3 species suggests a greater role in future speciation. All species having chromosomal races are heterostylous perennials. The longevity is perhaps what is needed to achieve the union between unreduced gametes (Baker, 1959) , while the outbreeding is probably a factor contributing to the reproductive success of the autotetraploids.

Although fossils are not known in the Hedyotideae, an evolutionary history of the subg. Edrisia can be suggested on the basis of data available for a majority of the extant species. With a dominant pantropical distribution in the modern flora, there is little question that the Rubiaceae had their major evolution in the tropics, possibly beginning as early as the Triassic or Jurassic followed by the exploitation of some extra-tropical environments in the Cretaceous (Axelrod, 1960) . The occurrence of the basic haploid number of x = 11 in many large and diverse tribes suggests a complement of some antiquity. Although the number may be a derived one (e.g., from prototypes with x = 5 and 6), the presence of x = 11 in nearly all modern woody tropical genera, genera which according to Darlington (1956) are least likely to be modified in chromosome number, indicates that this number is basic to most tribes, and therefore to the family as a whole.

The number most frequently found in the subg. Edrisia is x = 11. Such species are restricted in distribution to southwestern North America (Fig. 36) ; an area where early representatives of the subgenus could have readily colonized from more equatorial and lowland areas. It is supposed that the ancestors of the extant species had a basic number of x = 11 in what was probably a more widespread phylad in the moist forest belt of that region during the Cretaceous. The restriction of the neotropical flora in the Tertiary in response to cooling and to drying in western North America probably broke this continuity, a fragment of which survived by migration to the maritime climate of southern Baja California, while the main stock of x = 11 evolved into a highly endemic group of species. This phylogeny is supported by the morphological study (Table  3 ), in which those species of Baja California possess the most primitive combination of characters in the subgenus. These species may be relics of the subtropical Tertiary flora which survived by migrating to similar environmental conditions not requiring major adaptions, whereas those taxa not migrating were lost to the western flora or were able to adapt to the new, more rigorous habitats. The latter was a means of survival for the x = 11 group whose extant species illustrate a more advanced morphology than do those of Baja California, even without change in chromosome number from the neotropical phylad.

Chromosomal changes other than ascending aneuploidy to the west appear to have taken place in the x = 11 phylad forming a descending aneuploid series of x = 10, 9, 8, and 7. Individuals of H. nigricans having n = 10 are restricted in distribution to the western highland region occupied by the x = 11 species, but those having n = 9 are common to both the highland and eastern mesic environments. Plants with n = 10 are not easily distinguished from H. wrightii (n = 11) and it is not too speculative to suggest an origin from a taxon similar to H. wrightii by the loss of a chromosome pair. By additional loss the n = 9 individuals of H. nigricans of wide distribution in the southern United States must have formed and, on the basis of modern representation, are more successful. Although the morphology of the extant x = 8 species shows no close relationship to H. nigricans, the line probably arose from a taxon with x = 9, again, by the loss of chromosomes. The only species with n = 7, H. rosea, is morphologically similar to H. crassifolia (n = 8) and the more recent origin of the x = 7 line by additional chromosomal loss is indicated by the more advanced characteristics of H. rosea (Table  3 ) correlated with a more limited distribution (Fig. 39) .

The relationship of those species in the x = 6 line with the other groups in North America is not clear. It is difficult to suggest an origin from species with x = 7 wlien the small chromosomes of H. rosea (Fig. 7) are compared with the very large n = 6 chromosomes of H. longifolia, H. nuttalliana, and H. purpurea ( Fig. 1-3) . Also in striking contrast is the advanced morphological expressions of the x = 7 species and the primitive character of the x = 6 group, which hardly indicates that the latter group is of more recent origin
